title: CVPR_2011_10_abs

sentences.text: Reflections in image sequences consist of several layers superimposed over each other .
This phenomenon causes many image processing techniques to fail as they assume the presence of only one layer at each examined site e.g. motion estimation and object recognition .
This work presents an automated technique for detecting reflections in image sequences by analyzing motion trajectories of feature points .
It models reflection as regions containing two different layers moving over each other .
We present a strong detector based on combining a set of weak detectors .
We use novel priors , generate sparse and dense detection maps and our results show high detection rate with rejection to pathological motion and occlusion .

summary: Reflections in image sequences consist of several layers superimposed over each other . This phenomenon causes many image processing techniques to fail as they assume the presence of only one layer at each examined site e.g. motion estimation and object recognition . This work presents an automated technique for detecting reflections in image sequences by analyzing motion trajectories of feature points . It models reflection as regions containing two different layers moving over each other . We present a strong detector based on combining a set of weak detectors . We use novel priors , generate sparse and dense detection maps and our results show high detection rate with rejection to pathological motion and occlusion .

Predicate-causes.label: causes
Predicate-causes.description: The predicate 'causes' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject's existence or occurrence leads to or results in the state of being described by the object. In general, it implies a directional influence from the subject towards the object.

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: To present means to introduce or offer something as a solution, explanation, or representation. In this sense, it connects the subject (the entity providing the presentation) with the object (what is being presented), indicating that the subject has identified and made available the object for consideration, understanding, or application.

Predicate-detects.label: detects
Predicate-detects.description: The predicate 'detects' indicates that the subject has the ability to recognize or identify a specific pattern, feature, or phenomenon within its object. It implies a process of observation and analysis, where the subject extracts relevant information from the object.

Predicate-have.label: have
Predicate-have.description: The predicate 'have' indicates a relationship between the subject and object where the subject possesses or owns the object. This possession can be physical, abstract, conceptual, or even metaphorical. The connection between the subject and object implies that the subject has control over, is responsible for, or has some form of association with the object.

Predicate-models.label: models
Predicate-models.description: To model something means to create a representation or simulation of it, often for purposes such as analysis, prediction, or understanding. The predicate 'models' connects the subject and object by indicating that the subject has created or is creating an abstract or concrete representation of the object.

Predicate-present.label: present
Predicate-present.description: The predicate 'present' indicates the existence or occurrence of something in the current moment. It suggests that the subject has access to or possesses the object at this instant, emphasizing its relevance and significance.

Predicate-based_on_combining_a_set_of_we.label: based on combining a set of weak detectors
Predicate-based_on_combining_a_set_of_we.description: The predicate 'based on combining a set of weak detectors' indicates that the subject (a strong detector) relies on or derives its strength from the combination of multiple weaker detectors, which are represented by the object (set of weak detectors).

Predicate-generate.label: generate
Predicate-generate.description: To generate means to produce or create something from a given source or foundation. In this context, it implies that the subject (novel priors, for example) serves as the starting point or input for creating or producing the object (sparse and dense detection maps), which may involve transforming, processing, or combining information in some way.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: Indicates that the subject is a specific instance or member of a more general category or class denoted by the object.
